titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Ami Aloni Papers LSC.2406

did.abstract: The materials consist of written music, scores, and assorted paperwork related to the career of composer Ami Aloni. Aloni worked as a music director and composer for the film and television industry.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of David Aloni, Dan Aloni, and Dori Aloni Meshi, 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Ami Aloni papers (Collection 2406). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Elizabeth Gost, under the supervision of Jasmine Larkin, 2020. The original arrangement and folder titles created by Ami Aloni were retained.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biographical History
bioghist.p: Aminadav "Ami" Aloni (1928-1999) moved to New York at the age of 18, where he studied piano and composition at The Juilliard School of Music. Aloni moved to Los Angeles in the 1950s to work in the film and television industry. He served as music director and composer on television programs, telethons, and films. His work has been featured in various productions including The Great Waldo Pepper, Roots, and Exodus. He served at Valley Beth Shalom in Encino for 25 years as Music Director. Aloni also directed the synagogue choir. His compositions written for the synagogue include more than 100 commissions for the liturgy and dramatic work, which are performed in synagogues and concert halls across the United States and throughout the world.
Source: biographical information provided by donors, 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials consist of written music, scores, and assorted paperwork related to the career of composer Ami Aloni and include examples of his work as a music director and composer for the film and television industry where he worked on television series, telethons, and films. The collection also includes materials related to Aloni's 25 years working as music director and choir leader for Valley Beth Shalom in Encino. Also included are his over 100 commissioned compositions, which are performed in synagogues and concert halls throughout the world.
